utterances: I will take my answer off the phone.
Okay.
Okay, thank you.
Bye.
Okay.
Yeah.
It depends upon the organ that we're talking about.
But that most of us have some elements of benign tumors in our bodies at all times.

Why they suddenly become malignant - by malignant we mean that they grow larger and especially, that they can invade into surrounding tissue and they can spread to other parts of the body - that's one of the key questions that we are wrestling with right now in cancer research.
And clearly, the ability to start to attract the blood supply is part of that.
In the breast, ductal carcinoma in situ is a benign tumor that is found very, very commonly.
And most of the time, it doesn't do anything but occasionally, it does convert into a malignant tumor.
In men, there is something called PIN, which is a prostatic benign tumor that is very common as men get older.
Indeed, most men over age 50 and 60 have some evidence of that.
And that also can stay totally benign through your life or can convert.
So this is one of the really important topics in modern cancer research.
And…
Now, Dr…
Go ahead, Bob.
Dr.
Folkman was - has pointed out several times that autopsy studies in automobile accident victims show that almost everyone has these little tiny pinhead benign tumors in the thyroid gland.
So it's not uncommon, but what causes it to switch to malignancy is still not known.
It has something to do with oxygen starvation.
But they're still working on that.
Bob, in the book, again, you described a couple of, you know, individuals who were quite remarkable - successfully treated with some of these angiogenesis inhibitors, angiostatin and endostatin.
How far along, in general, have these drugs gotten, do you think?
Well, they're really doing very well.
I was at his laboratory this morning.
Of course, Judah Folkman isn't there having died two weeks ago.
But the research is continuing at terrifically rapid pace.
And some of the angiogenesis inhibitors that he found are now fast approaching the clinic.

At first, when they were introduced in about, oh, probably 2000 or 1999, the toxicity test suggested that there might be efficacy but not enough to get a - people to get excited about, so they have never made it to the clinic.
That may soon change.
Dr.
Norton, is that your understanding?
I mean, are these drugs - these - not, I guess, not necessarily specifically these, but drugs based on the controlling blood supply, is that likely to become important in treating solid tumors?
Well, it's actually already important.
Uh-huh.
Yeah.
Well, we like the trailer.
This - the drug Avastin, or bevacizumab is what it's called, is actually already in use in the clinic in several diseases and we're studying in other diseases.
There's about a dozen drugs in development, including the drugs that Bob just mentioned that are being developed right now that are rapidly approaching proper clinical trials.
Of course, we have to learn a lot about them - toxicities, the right dose, the right schedule.
There's a lot of work that's yet to be done.

But without question, the fact that we have at least one anti-blood vessel drug that's on the market and that is helping people at controlling the cancers indicates that Judah was right, this is an important target.

But again - now, this is - I guess, the question that I want to get at and it's very hard for me as a journalist to talk about Judah Folkman's work without thinking about a famous New York Times article which quoted Jim Watson as saying, Judah Folkman is going to cure cancer in two years.
He obviously didn't do that and maybe, it was an over-the-top comment even at the time, and intentionally so.
But the point is, how big of a contribution is this?
I mean, is this going to - I mean, are 20 percent of cancer victims going to be saved - lives saved or is it 5 percent or is it 50 percent?
I mean, can you say how big of a contribution these will ultimately be?
Well, of course, you can't.
You know, it could be huge.
It's certainly a contributing factor.

But let me tell you something about it that is huge, which is that that work shifted the attention of a very large segment of our community - and the entire cancer research community acknowledges the importance of this, shifted it from just the cancer cell to the relationship of the cancer cell and its normal environment.
Many of the blood vessel cells that come - that form these new blood vessels in cancers are coming from the bone marrow.
Indeed, some people think they're all coming from the bone marrow and they're circulating through the system, getting to the area of the tumor and that's where the blood vessel growth really starts.
And it shows you that cancer's not just a disease of the cancer cell but it's a disease of the cells around the cancer cell, indeed, the bone marrow and the whole body.
And that change of focus is huge.
And that - the implications of that are really enormous for understanding biology and unquestionably are going to help a lot of people and, many of us believe, will lead to the cure of cancer.
Okay.
Let's take one more call now and go to Terry(ph) in Hilton Head, South Carolina.
Go ahead.
Yes.
Welcome to the program.
Hi.
Thanks.
I have a question.
I was listening regarding the increase in vascular tissue and oxygen the tumor grows.
And I'm wondering is there any sort of inverse relationship between anemia and tumor growth.
And I'll take my answer off the air.
Thank you.
Okay.
Thank you.
Dr. Norton, anything about anemia and cancer growth?
Anemia itself does not make tumors grow faster or make them grow less.
But often, cancers actually can cause anemia.
There's an anemia of malignancy that we sometimes observe.
So the cancers are actually sending out signals throughout the body for the body to produce fewer red blood cells.
And again, it indicates that a cancer is not just a lump of cells that are just sort of growing, but they're related to the whole body.
Okay.
Let's try one more - oh, sorry, Bob Cooke, go ahead.
The picture that seems to be emerging is that a tiny tumor growing until it reaches a certain size and can't grow without more blood, which suggests it's starving for oxygen and nutrients.
And when any organ in the body is starving, it sends out a signal: Send me more blood.
Send me more blood.
And that may be part of the angiogenic switch that makes the body start sending in new blood vessels.
Okay.
One final question from Jim(ph) in Indianapolis, Minnesota.
Indianapolis, Minnesota, is that right, did I say that right?
Indiana?
Minneapolis, Minnesota.
There we are.
Okay, Minnesota.
Welcome to the program.
Nice to be on.
I have a - I run a company here.

I've just returned to work after eating my lunch, after I had my Avastin treatment for my - I'm in 10 years and I've been blessed with doctors that are really thinking outside the box, resources like the Lance Armstrong Foundation that helped me find the new treatment.
And Avastin is working against a high-grade - like my tumor has shifted from a lower grade to a higher grade, and I'm using it in combination with several chemotherapy agents.
And just - I'm blessed I'm responding.

From what I understand, I've been following it for a long time, that this was really creative research that people weren't supporting for a long time and it's really, you know, for me, personally, it's making all the difference for me.
And I'm getting back to work, and I've got a family.
How can we encourage people to do this creative research that seems to be not favored?
And it's been more of the, if you have the specific research that is just making incremental progress may not be the huge breakthroughs like this.
Well…
How do we encourage that and how do we even encourage people to get in the clinical trials to do these sorts of things like I have that are really making the difference?
Well, Jim, we wish you good luck and thanks for that really interesting question.
Bob Cooke, go ahead.
You know, the problem is if industry can't see a huge profit in it, they're not going to invest in something that doesn't look that it's going to work soon.
Years ago, there was a representative who came through the Folkman Lab, popped his feet up and lit a cigar and said, okay, what do you got that I'd quit the bottle(ph) in six months?
Well, it doesn't work that way.
And in the meantime, we have Robert Daniels there in Arizona.
He is apparently, effectively, a prisoner.
And the anti-angiogenesis treatments, when they give them to patients, don't cause a quick reduction in tumor size.
It takes a long time to drive it into what you might call dormancy.
It is not a quick change, but it's a very, very profound change.
Okay.
Larry Norton, we give you the final word on this.
Yeah.
Well, I - this is a big topic, and I'll try to do this as succinctly as I possibly can.
You know, thank goodness for industry because industry right now supplies almost half the money that's in cancer research in the United States.
If you add together all of the money that all Americans spent on cancer research - philanthropy, government and industry - it's only two-thirds of what Americans spent on tobacco advertising.
And so if you really want more advances, you've got to prime the pump.
It's got to be supported.
And if there is enough activity, then some of that activity will truly be creative.

When you have an environment where people are starved of research funds, they're not going to be very creative, they have to be very conservative or they're going to lose their funding or not get their funding.
And so if we really care about cancer research, Americans really have to get behind this.
And I hope all our presidential candidates hear this message.
Okay.
Well, we have to leave it there.
I'd like to thank my guests for this segment.
Robert Cooke, was the - is the author of ""Dr.
Folkman's War: Angiogenesis and the Struggle to Defeat Cancer.
Also joining me was Dr. Larry Norton.
He is the deputy-in-chief of breast cancer programs at the Memorial - Sloan Memorial Cancer Center here in New York City.
The college football season is in full swing with its pageantry and rivalries.
Commentator and Florida State Seminoles fan Diane Roberts is feeling some ambivalence.
She's a feminist who loves football.
I know.
I know.
The game reinforces the most retrograde gender roles.
The men are front and center hitting each other.
The women stay on the sidelines encouraging the men to hit each other.
Look at the clothes for god sake.
The cheerleaders wear short skirts and eyeliner.
The players wear tight britches and huge shoulder pads.
The game is a feast of hyper masculinity with a side order of phallic metaphor: penetration, scoring.
It's stylized warfare, fighting over 100 yards worth of symbolic turf.
The object being to march deeper and deeper into enemy territory.
the bomb, the shotgun, the sack.
The only time the game gets in touch with its feminine side is when, say, you're on your own, 25, down by six with seven seconds to go in the fourth, then you throw the Hail Mary.
As usual, the men get themselves into trouble and expect a women to bail them out.
I know.
I know.

No thinking person, no lover of peace and good manners and human decency, and especially no feminist has any business spending Saturday afternoon with 80,000 semi-drunk people hollering, kill him, at a bunch of 20-year-old boys, who may or may not know that the polarized caps are melting or who may or may not have read Virginia Woolf.
I was a fan before I was a feminist.
I started going to Florida State games at the age of nine.
After my father died, I inherited his season tickets.
He loved the game.
I love the game.
I know I shouldn't, but I do.
I love the elegance with which a quarterback throws.
For a fraction of a second, just before he releases the ball, he poses with the grace of a Greek statue.
